claim: SOS did not originally stand for anything.

supporting.text: The Morse code distress signal 'SOS' was formally introduced in 1908 as a standardized maritime distress signal, and it was chosen for its simplicity and distinctiveness, not as an acronym for any phrase.

attacks.text: The Morse code distress signal 'SOS' was formally introduced in 1908 as a standardized maritime distress signal, and it was chosen for its simplicity and distinctiveness, not as an acronym for any phrase.
Some historical documents suggest that 'SOS' was later retroactively associated with phrases like 'Save Our Souls' or 'Save Our Ship' due to its phonetic resemblance.
The retroactive association of 'SOS' with phrases like 'Save Our Souls' is a folk etymology and lacks formal documentation from the time of its adoption.
Early wireless operators occasionally used 'CQD' as a distress signal before 'SOS' was standardized, indicating that 'SOS' may have been chosen partly due to existing practices.
While 'CQD' was used, it was not as universally recognized or as simple as 'SOS', which is why 'SOS' was adopted as the standard.

supporting.text: Historical records from the International Radiotelegraph Convention of 1906 and 1908 show that 'SOS' was adopted without any official meaning attached to the letters.

attacks.text: Historical records from the International Radiotelegraph Convention of 1906 and 1908 show that 'SOS' was adopted without any official meaning attached to the letters.
Some maritime historians argue that 'SOS' was informally interpreted as 'Save Our Souls' or 'Save Our Ship' by operators, even if not officially designated.
The informal interpretations like 'Save Our Souls' emerged later in popular culture and were not part of the original adoption or usage in early radiotelegraphy.
Early telegraphy manuals and training materials sometimes included mnemonic meanings for 'SOS,' suggesting some intentionality behind the letters.
These mnemonic meanings were likely added for memorization purposes and do not reflect the official stance of the International Radiotelegraph Convention.

supporting.text: Early usage of 'SOS' in maritime and telegraphic contexts did not associate the signal with phrases like 'Save Our Souls' or 'Save Our Ship'; these were later popular interpretations.

attacks.text: Early usage of 'SOS' in maritime and telegraphic contexts did not associate the signal with phrases like 'Save Our Souls' or 'Save Our Ship'; these were later popular interpretations.
Some historical documents from the early 1900s mention 'Save Our Souls' in relation to SOS, suggesting the association may have existed earlier than commonly believed.
The 'Save Our Souls' association was likely retroactively applied by the public or media, as official maritime records from the time do not support this interpretation.
The SOS signal was chosen for its simplicity in Morse code, not for any acronymic meaning, which supports the claim that it did not originally stand for anything.
Even if SOS was chosen for its Morse code simplicity, it could have still been informally associated with phrases like 'Save Our Souls' early on, despite not being officially recognized.

supporting.text: Linguistic analysis of the term 'SOS' confirms that it was not derived from any existing phrase or acronym in English or other languages at the time of its adoption.

attacks.text: Linguistic analysis of the term 'SOS' confirms that it was not derived from any existing phrase or acronym in English or other languages at the time of its adoption.
Historical records indicate that 'SOS' was sometimes informally interpreted as 'Save Our Souls' or 'Save Our Ship' shortly after its adoption, suggesting folk etymology influenced its perception.
The informal interpretations like 'Save Our Souls' emerged later and were not part of the original intent or design of the 'SOS' signal, which was purely a Morse code sequence.
Some early 20th-century documents reference 'SOS' alongside phrases like 'Send Out Succor,' indicating that acronymic interpretations existed contemporaneously with its use.

These documents are rare and likely reflect localized or anecdotal usage rather than formal standardization, as the International Radiotelegraph Convention explicitly defined 'SOS' as a procedural signal.

supporting.text: Authoritative sources such as the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and maritime safety organizations state that 'SOS' was never officially an acronym.

attacks.text: Authoritative sources such as the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and maritime safety organizations state that 'SOS' was never officially an acronym.

Some historical documents and Morse code training materials from the early 20th century suggest 'SOS' was interpreted as 'Save Our Souls' or 'Save Our Ship' by operators, implying it was unofficially treated as an acronym.

The interpretations 'Save Our Souls' and 'Save Our Ship' are post-hoc rationalizations, not original meanings, as confirmed by primary sources from the time of adoption (e.g., 1908 Berlin Radio Conference).
The ITU's stance is a modern formalization; contemporaneous usage in maritime distress calls often treated 'SOS' as carrying implied meaning due to its memorability.
Memorability does not equate to acronym status. The ITU's records explicitly state 'SOS' was chosen for its distinct Morse pattern, not linguistic meaning.
